message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Changing fitness effects of mutations through long-term bacterial evolution
Paper Abstract: The distribution of fitness effects of new mutations shapes evolution, but it is challenging to observe how it changes as organisms adapt. Using Escherichia coli lineages spanning 50,000 generations of evolution, we quantify the fitness effects of insertion mutations in every gene. Macroscopically, the fraction of deleterious mutations changed little over time whereas the beneficial tail declined sharply, approaching an exponential distribution. Microscopically, changes in individual gene essentiality and deleterious effects often occurred in parallel; altered essentiality is only partly explained by structural variation. The identity and effect sizes of beneficial mutations changed rapidly over time, but many targets of selection remained predictable because of the importance of loss-of-function mutations. Taken together, these results reveal the dynamic—but statistically predictable—nature of mutational fitness effects.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's an overview of Escherichia coli bacteria based on the search results:

## Basic Characteristics

Escherichia coli is a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic, rod-shaped, coliform bacterium of the genus Escherichia that is commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms.

## Discovery and Naming

In 1885, the German-Austrian pediatrician Theodor Escherich discovered this organism in the feces of healthy individuals. He called it Bacterium coli commune because it is found in the colon.(no content)It was later reclassified in the newly created genus Escherichia, named after its original discoverer, by Aldo Castellani and Albert John Chalmers.

## Diversity and Health Impact

Escherichia coli is one of the most diverse bacterial species, with several pathogenic strains with different symptoms and with only 20% of the genome common to all strains.(no content)Certain strains of some species, most notably the pathogenic serotypes of E. coli, are human pathogens, and are the most common cause of urinary tract infections, significant sources of gastrointestinal disease, ranging from simple diarrhea to dysentery-like conditions.

## Model Organism in Research

E. coli is frequently used as a model organism in microbiology studies.(no content)E. coli was one of the first organisms to have its genome sequenced; the complete genome of E. coli K12 was published by Science in 1997.

Links: [{"title":"Darwinism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darwinism"},{"title":"On the Origin of Species - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/On_the_Origin_of_Species"},{"title":"Charles Darwin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Darwin"},{"title":"History of evolutionary thought - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_evolutionary_thought"},{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Natural selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_selection"},{"title":"Evolution: The Triumph of an Idea - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution:_The_Triumph_of_an_Idea"},{"title":"Development of Darwin's theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Development_of_Darwin's_theory"},{"title":"Evolutionary biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_biology"},{"title":"Publication of Darwin's theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Publication_of_Darwin's_theory"}]

I've completed the web search for "evolution biology Darwin". Here are the key findings:

## Darwin and Evolution

Charles Darwin was an English naturalist and biologist who introduced the scientific theory that evolution resulted from a process of natural selection, in which the struggle for existence has a similar effect to the artificial selection involved in selective breeding.

## The Theory of Evolution by Natural Selection

Darwin's "On the Origin of Species" is considered to be the foundation of evolutionary biology.(no content)It was published on 24 November 1859.(no content)The theory states that all species of organisms arise and develop through the natural selection of small, inherited variations that increase the individual's ability to compete, survive, and reproduce.

## Key Concepts

Darwin's proposition that all species of life have descended from a common ancestor is now generally accepted and considered a fundamental scientific concept.(no content)Natural selection is the differential survival and reproduction of individuals due to differences in the relative fitness endowed on them by their own particular complement of observable characteristics.

## Impact on Biology

Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that analyzes the four mechanisms of evolution: natural selection, mutation, genetic drift, and gene flow.(no content)Debate over Darwin's work led to the rapid acceptance of the general concept of evolution, but the specific mechanism he proposed, natural selection, was not widely accepted until it was revived by developments in biology that occurred during the 1920s through the 1940s.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "fitness evolution biology"

Links: [{"title":"Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"Fitness (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology)"},{"title":"Inclusive fitness in humans - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusive_fitness_in_humans"},{"title":"Evolutionary tradeoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_tradeoff"},{"title":"Survival of the fittest - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survival_of_the_fittest"},{"title":"Evolutionary landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_landscape"},{"title":"Selection coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selection_coefficient"},{"title":"Evolutionary invasion analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_invasion_analysis"},{"title":"Fecundity selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fecundity_selection"}]

Based on the web search results, here's information about fitness evolution in biology:

## What is Fitness in Evolutionary Biology?

In evolutionary biology, fitness is a quantitative representation of individual reproductive success and is equal to the average contribution to the gene pool of the next generation, made by the same individuals of the specified genotype or phenotype.(no content)The biological concept of fitness is defined as reproductive success, which in Darwinian terms is best understood as "survival of the form that in successive generations will leave most copies of itself."

## Historical Development

The British-Indian biologist J.B.S. Haldane was the first to quantify fitness, in terms of the modern evolutionary synthesis of Darwinism and Mendelian genetics starting with his 1924 paper A Mathematical Theory of Natural and Artificial Selection.(no content)The next further advance was the introduction of the concept of inclusive fitness by the British biologist W.D. Hamilton in 1964 in his paper on The Genetical Evolution of Social Behaviour.

## Key Concepts

**Fitness Landscapes:** In evolutionary biology, fitness landscapes or adaptive landscapes are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.

**Evolutionary Tradeoffs:** In evolutionary biology, an evolutionary tradeoff is a situation in which evolution cannot advance one part of a biological system without distressing another part of it, where tradeoffs refer to the process through which a trait increases in fitness at the expense of decreased fitness in another trait.

**Selection Coefficient:** Selection coefficient, usually denoted by the letter s, is a measure used in population genetics to quantify the relative fitness of a genotype compared to other genotypes, and selection coefficients are central to the quantitative description of evolution, since fitness differences determine the change in genotype frequencies attributable to selection.

Web search results for query: "mutation biology genetics"

Links: [{"title":"Mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation"},{"title":"Mutant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutant"},{"title":"Mutationism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutationism"},{"title":"Mutation rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_rate"},{"title":"Point mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Point_mutation"},{"title":"Genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics"},{"title":"Molecular genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Molecular_genetics"},{"title":"Mutagenesis (molecular biology technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutagenesis_(molecular_biology_technique)#:~:text=Such techniques commonly involve using,of DNA at specific sites."},{"title":"Gene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene"},{"title":"De novo mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_novo_mutation"}]

Here are the search results for "mutation biology genetics":

## Definition and Overview

In biology, a mutation is an alteration in the nucleic acid sequence of the genome of an organism, virus, or extrachromosomal DNA.(no content)Mutations result from errors during DNA or viral replication, mitosis, or meiosis or other types of damage to DNA (such as pyrimidine dimers caused by exposure to ultraviolet radiation), which then may undergo error-prone repair or cause an error during replication.

## Effects and Significance

Mutations may or may not produce detectable changes in the observable characteristics (phenotype) of an organism.(no content)Mutations play a part in both normal and abnormal biological processes including: evolution, cancer, and the development of the immune system.(no content)Mutation is the ultimate source of all genetic variation, providing the raw material on which evolutionary forces such as natural selection can act.

## Types of Mutations

Several types of mutations exist in genetics:

- **Point Mutations**: A point mutation is a genetic mutation where a single nucleotide base is changed, inserted or deleted from a DNA or RNA sequence of an organism's genome.

- **De Novo Mutations**: A de novo mutation is any mutation or alteration in the genome of an individual organism that was not inherited from its parents.

## Medical Significance

In cancer, somatic point mutations can inactivate tumor suppressors or hyperactivate oncogenes, fueling uncontrolled cell growth. Thousands of point-mutation-driven conditions have been cataloged—from relatively common disorders like sickle-cell anemia and cystic fibrosis to extremely rare syndromes.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about gene essentiality and essential genes:

## Definition

Essential genes are indispensable genes for organisms to grow and reproduce offspring under certain environment. More specifically, essential genes are the set of genes thought to be critical for an organism's survival, assuming the abundant availability of all relevant nutrients and the absence of environmental stress.

## Contextual Nature of Essentiality

Being essential is highly dependent on the circumstances in which an organism lives. For instance, a gene required to digest starch is only essential if starch is the only source of energy.

## Number of Essential Genes by Organism

Essential gene numbers vary significantly across different organisms:

- **Bacteria**: In bacteria, an estimated 250–400 genes are essential for Escherichia coli and Bacillus subtilis, which is less than 10% of their genes.

- **Yeast**: In Saccharomyces cerevisiae (budding yeast) 15-20% of all genes are essential.

- **Higher eukaryotes**: Mice and humans are estimated to have around 2000 essential genes (~10% of their genes).

## Functions of Essential Genes

Essential genes of single-celled organisms encode proteins for three basic functions including genetic information processing, cell envelopes and energy production. Those gene functions are used to maintain a central metabolism, replicate DNA, translate genes into proteins, maintain a basic cellular structure, and mediate transport processes into and out of the cell.

## Methods for Identification

Two main strategies have been employed to identify essential genes on a genome-wide basis: directed deletion of genes and random mutagenesis using transposons. Additionally, with the development of CRISPR, gene essentiality has also been determined through inhibition of gene expression through CRISPR interference.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "structural variation genomics"

Links: [{"title":"Structural variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_variation"},{"title":"Structural variation in the human genome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_variation_in_the_human_genome"},{"title":"Genetic variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_variation"},{"title":"Human genetic variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_genetic_variation"},{"title":"Human variability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_variability"},{"title":"Copy number variation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Copy_number_variation"},{"title":"1000 Genomes Project - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1000_Genomes_Project"},{"title":"Comparative genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparative_genomics"},{"title":"Genome instability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genome_instability"},{"title":"Structural genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Structural_genomics"}]

I've completed a web search on "structural variation genomics." Here's what I found:

## Overview of Structural Variation in Genomics

Genomic structural variation is the variation in structure of an organism's chromosome, such as deletions, duplications, copy-number variants, insertions, inversions and translocations.(no content)Structural variation in the human genome is operationally defined as genomic alterations, varying between individuals, that involve DNA segments larger than 1 kilo base (kb), and could be either microscopic or submicroscopic.

## Scale and Significance

A structure variation originally affected asequence length about 1kb to 3Mb, which is larger than SNPs and smaller than chromosome abnormality, though the operational range of structural variants has widened to include events > 50bp.(no content)Approximately 13% of the human genome is defined as structurally variant in the normal population, and there are at least 240 genes that exist as homozygous deletion polymorphisms in human populations, suggesting these genes are dispensable in humans.

## Impact on Human Genetic Variation

While humans carry a median of 3.6 Mbp in SNPs (compared to a reference genome), a median of 8.9 Mbp is affected by structural variation which thus causes most genetic differences between humans.

## Types of Structural Variants

According to the 1000 Genomes Project, a typical human has 2,100 to 2,500 structural variations, which include approximately 1,000 large deletions, 160 copy-number variants, 915 Alu insertions, 128 L1 insertions, 51 SVA insertions, 4 NUMTs, and 10 inversions.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "insertion sequence transposon insertion mutation"

Links: [{"title":"Insertion sequence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insertion_sequence"},{"title":"Transposon sequencing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_sequencing"},{"title":"Transposon mutagenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposon_mutagenesis"},{"title":"Insertional mutagenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Insertional_mutagenesis"},{"title":"DNA transposon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DNA_transposon"},{"title":"Transposable element - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposable_element"},{"title":"Transposase - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Transposase"},{"title":"Conservative transposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservative_transposition"},{"title":"Inverted repeat - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inverted_repeat"},{"title":"Transposons as a genetic tool - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transposons_as_a_genetic_tool"}]

I've performed a web search on insertion sequences, transposons, and insertion mutations. Here's what the results show:

## Key Findings:

**Insertion Sequences (IS elements):**
Insertion sequences are small relative to other transposable elements (generally around 700 to 2500 bp in length) and only code for proteins implicated in the transposition activity.

**Transposon Insertion and Mutation:**
When a transposon inserts itself in a gene, the gene's function will be disrupted. Because of that property, transposons have been manipulated for use in insertional mutagenesis.(no content)In molecular biology, insertional mutagenesis is the creation of mutations in DNA by the addition of one or more base pairs. Such insertional mutations can occur naturally, mediated by viruses or transposons, or can be artificially created for research purposes in the lab.

**Mechanism of Insertion:**
As newly inserted DNA into active coding sequences, DNA transposons can disrupt normal protein functions and cause mutations.(no content)The transposase makes a staggered cut at the target site producing sticky ends, cuts out the DNA transposon and ligates it into the target site. A DNA polymerase fills in the resulting gaps from the sticky ends and DNA ligase closes the sugar-phosphate backbone. This results in target site duplication.

**Applications:**
Currently transposons can be used in genetic research and recombinant genetic engineering for insertional mutagenesis. Insertional mutagenesis is when transposons function as vectors to help remove and integrate genetic sequences.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Because of that property, transposons have been manipulated for use in insertional mutagenesis.(no content)In molecular biology, insertional mutagenesis is the creation of mutations in DNA by the addition of one or more base pairs. Such insertional mutations can occur naturally, mediated by viruses or transposons, or can be artificially created for research purposes in the lab.

**Mechanism of Insertion:**
As newly inserted DNA into active coding sequences, DNA transposons can disrupt normal protein functions and cause mutations.(no content)The transposase makes a staggered cut at the target site producing sticky ends, cuts out the DNA transposon and ligates it into the target site. A DNA polymerase fills in the resulting gaps from the sticky ends and DNA ligase closes the sugar-phosphate backbone. This results in target site duplication.

**Applications:**
Currently transposons can be used in genetic research and recombinant genetic engineering for insertional mutagenesis. Insertional mutagenesis is when transposons function as vectors to help remove and integrate genetic sequences.

Based on the search results, here's information about loss-of-function mutations and knockdowns:

## Loss-of-Function Mutations

Loss-of-function mutations, also called inactivating mutations, result in the gene product having less or no function (being partially or wholly inactivated).(no content)When the allele has a complete loss of function (null allele), it is often called an amorph or amorphic mutation, and phenotypes associated with such mutations are most often recessive.(no content)Examples of diseases caused by a loss-of-function mutation include Gitelman syndrome and cystic fibrosis.

## Knockdown Approaches

Gene knockdown is a research technique used to study gene function by reducing gene expression. Gene silencing is often considered the same as gene knockdown. When genes are silenced, their expression is reduced. In contrast, when genes are knocked out, they are completely erased from the organism's genome and, thus, have no expression.

Several methods can achieve knockdown:

- **RNA Interference (RNAi)**: RNA interference (RNAi) is a means of silencing genes by way of mRNA degradation. Gene knockdown by this method is achieved by introducing small double-stranded interfering RNAs (siRNA) into the cytoplasm.

- **Morpholino Antisense Oligos**: A simple alternative for gene knockdown is Morpholino antisense oligos. Morpholinos bind and block access to the target mRNA without requiring the activity of cellular proteins and without necessarily accelerating mRNA degradation.(no content)The most direct use of transient knockdowns is for learning about a gene that has been sequenced, but has an unknown or incompletely known function. This experimental approach is known as reverse genetics. Researchers draw inferences from how the knockdown differs from individuals in which the gene of interest is operational.

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Changing fitness effects of mutations through long-term bacterial evolution" and extracted all key entities with their relationships.

### Paper Classification
**Type:** Contribution (proposes new analysis and characterization)

### Extracted Triples (9 total)

| Entity | Relation | Type | Wikipedia Link | Relevance |
|--------|----------|------|---|---|
| Distribution of fitness effects | **proposes** | concept | [Fitness landscape](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape) | Novel characterization of how fitness effect distributions change during evolution |
| Mutation | uses | concept | [Mutation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation) | Fundamental genetic variation source analyzed in the study |
| Fitness (biology) | uses | concept | [Fitness (biology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_(biology)) | Core measurement of individual reproductive success |
